commit.message:
DB-10967 added splice.function.timestampFormat

e.g.
call SYSCS_UTIL.SYSCS_SET_GLOBAL_DATABASE_PROPERTY( 'splice.function.timestampFormat', 'yyyy-MM-dd-HH.mm.ss.SSSSSSSS'); -- IBM style

nodes.bodyText: I think you can remove this method.
timestampPrecisionString can be removed along with the related logic from GenericStatement.

commit.message: DB-10967 code review: remove timestampPrecision, some refactoring

nodes.bodyText:
I would elevate it to a standard SQL exception with an error code. DB2 throws error with SQLState 22007 if one attempts e.g. the following:
INSERT INTO t1 (c1) VALUES (TIMESTAMP_FORMAT('1999-12-31 23:59:59', 'YYYY-MM-sadsdDD HH24:MI:SXXXS'))

SQL20447N  Format string "YYYY-MM-sadsdDD HH24:MI:SXXXS" is not valid for the 
"SYSIBM.TIMESTAMP_FORMAT" function.  SQLSTATE=22007

I suggest to use the same here.
I guess this would also throw if we have a pattern that looks like this: yyyy----MM-dd HH:mm:ss (notice the tripple-dash), do we want to allow such pattern?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -169,12 +172,57 @@ public int estimateMemoryUsage()
         return BASE_MEMORY_USAGE;
     } // end of estimateMemoryUsage
 
-    private static String format(Timestamp timestamp, String timeStampFormat) {
+    /**
+     * this also checks if the format is a valid fixed-size timestamp format
+     * see also https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/time/format/DateTimeFormatter.html
+     * we support:
+     * yyyy, yy, uuuu, uu, eee, EEE, MM, mm, dd, HH, hh, ss, a
+     * an arbitrary number of S, and other characters " ,.-/:"
+     * @param format
+     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if format is not supported
+     * @return length of format
+     */
+    public static int getFormatLength(String format) throws IllegalArgumentException

commit.message:
DB-10973 fixing cast result of timestamps / upper(timestamp(...))

+ addressed code review

nodes.bodyText: Not quite related to this PR, but that one seems to only be used in SpliceAdmin and should therefore probably be moved out of this class.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -98,8 +102,7 @@
     public static final String defaultTimestampFormatString = "yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss";

nodes.bodyText: The current maximum on-disk timestamp precision is 6 decimal places.  Maybe we should make the default timestamp format match this.  Having a default format with 9 decimal places might make users mistakenly think they can input such data into tables as well.
